Award.AwardTitle: Using an Ecological Framework to Examine Reporting of Abuse During Incarceration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The U.S. Department of Justice (2012) estimates that there are between 149,200 and 209,400 incidents of sexual victimization annually in prisons and jails, incurring an estimated cost of $52 billion. Yet, less than 8% of those experiencing sexual victimization during incarceration report it to correctional authorities. This project addresses the question, what are the predictors of reporting and do they differ based on the reporting mechanism?

The goal of this project is to provide relevant social science evidence that will inform both legal policies and institutional practices by: 1) assessing the processes and outcomes associated with reporting externally and pursuing litigation; 2) identifying and understanding the individual- and system-level factors that influence prison reporting; and, 3) assessing processes and case outcomes for those who did report to prison authorities. Data to be analyzed are from 474 women, and their legal files, involved in a class action suit based upon experiences of sexual victimization during incarceration. Multiple methods will be used to understand decisions regarding reporting including the barriers, consequences, and benefits, including a survey, review/analysis of archival legal data, case review, and process mapping. The archival review design is advantageous in that it allows for the collection of victimization information without re-traumatizing or endangering vulnerable individuals, maximizes partnerships between social science researchers and legal practitioners, and uses existing data that would otherwise be difficult or impossible to obtain. The ecological framework underlying this research incorporates various levels of social ecology (individual, micro, meso, macro), providing theory that illuminates individual level behavior, as well as the unique aspects of the prison system and policy that inform institutional practices. Examining the processes and outcomes of both internal and external reporting mechanisms can assist prisons nationally in assessing their own institutional practices toward sexual victimization, potentially reducing risk and costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. Department of Justice estimates that the annual cost of sexual victimization within prisons, jails, and juvenile detention facilities is $51.9 billion. These costs are computed based on the number of individuals victimized yearly (between 209,400 and 149,200), medical/mental health care (i.e. suicide, sexually transmitted disease, pregnancy, substance abuse, victim services), and the criminal justice investigation and sanctioning associated with sexual victimization. Prevention was the goal of the 2003 Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA), but the problem remains, in part due to the low reporting of abuse.

Although there has been research on processes associated with reporting sexual victimization in community settings, there has been little analysis focused on reporting within prison. The overarching goal of this project was to provide relevant social science data that informs current policies and practices as they relate to the reporting of sexual victimization in prisons and other closed institutional settings.

Assessing the reporting of sexual victimization is challenging in any context; however, such an assessment within a prison context has unique challenges. First, perpetrators of sexual victimization within prison can be inmates or staff. Although all sexual contact between staff and inmates is legally nonconsensual, half of sexual victimization within prison is perpetrated by staff. Given conditions of confinement (no autonomy to seek help), and the power imbalance between staff and inmates (staff has the authority to approve or deny any request), reporting staff sexual misconduct is particularly difficult to execute and assess. A related challenge is the limited access to information and data. Prisons are a closed institutional settings and observation, access to inmates, and attempts to collect data is highly regulated. Therefore, most studies of prison-based reporting are based upon hypothetical vignettes or official records of those who did report (about 8 % of those victimized).

As a remedy to this data access issue, legal case files, resulting from a class action lawsuit of 809 women victimized during incarceration, provided extant data for secondary analysis. The availability of the legal case file data provided an unobtrusive method of data collection that protected women from further institutional and psychological risks, creating an opportunity to study reporting phenomena. Although men are the majority of those incarcerated – similar data does not exist for males and would be difficult to replicate. Moreover, most studies on reporting victimization within the community-setting have been conducted with female samples.

Using multiple methods (i.e., extraction from existing litigation files, surveys from affected individuals) the study answers three primary questions.

(1) How satisfied are women with the outcome of the litigation? Surveys were obtained from 39% of the sample, measuring perceptions of both the process of the litigation (procedural justice) and the case outcomes in terms of settlement and changes within the prison (distributive justice). Overall, women were more positive if they joined the litigation “because it was the right thing to do” and were less satisfied if they felt there was little improvement in prison practices. There was also less satisfaction among women who wanted individual staff members punished – something that is not possible with class action litigation. The size of the settlement was inversely related to perceptions of justice.

(2) What differentiates those who reported sexual victimization to prison authorities from those who did not? The litigation data provided a naturally occurring comparison group resulting in our ability to examine the characteristics of those who did and did not report to prison administrators. The final model revealed that that six factors predicted whether a women would report staff sexual misconduct (younger age at time of assault; presence of physical injury; experiencing a single incident; if the perpetrator did not have multiple victims; if the abuse began later in terms of years of the case; and women who would be released sooner). These predictors illuminate specific vulnerability within the prison and can be used to inform interventions within such as opportunities to disclose to individuals outside the prison.

(3) What does the process of reporting look like and how might it be improved? Using a sub sample of women who experienced the most serious victimization (n=184), we found 56% reported and that most experienced threats and/or retaliation from staff members. Of those reported, less than half (48%) were investigated even though departmental policy mandates investigation of staff misconduct. Those that were investigated tended to report more often or report through more formal mechanisms (i.e. a written grievance on an officer versus verbal report).  The majority of cases (51%) were unsustained, meaning that there was not enough evidence to prove or disprove that the abuse occurred.

Our team has published multiple manuscripts, presented at conferences, and is working on products that can be disseminated to key policy stakeholders and prison administrators.  PREA implementation requires strengthening and information here will assist in those endeavors.
